description: Key nutrition indicators for program monitoring and evaluation

process.label: Process Indicators
process.description: Measure program activities and delivery quality

output.label: Output Indicators
output.description: Measure direct results of program activities

outcome.label: Outcome Indicators
outcome.description: Measure changes in beneficiary status or behavior

indicators.name: Stunting Prevalence
indicators.definition: Percentage of children under 5 years with height-for-age z-score (HAZ) below -2 standard deviations from WHO reference median
indicators.numerator: Number of children 0-59 months with HAZ < -2
indicators.denominator: Total number of children 0-59 months measured
indicators.targetValue: Varies by context; WHO critical threshold >30%
indicators.dataSource: Household surveys (DHS, MICS, SMART) or program anthropometric data
indicators.collectionMethod: Anthropometric measurement (height/length boards, trained measurers, standardized technique)
indicators.frequency: Baseline, midterm, endline for programs. Annually or bi-annually for monitoring.

interpretation.high: > 30% is very high; indicates chronic, long-term malnutrition
interpretation.medium: 20-29% is high; significant public health problem
interpretation.low: 10-19% is medium; moderate public health concern
interpretation.veryLow: < 10% is low; acceptable for most contexts

limitations: Reflects cumulative exposure over time; changes slowly
Requires large sample sizes to detect change
Measurement error can be substantial
Does not reflect acute nutritional stress
indicators.technicalNotes: Use WHO Anthro software for calculating z-scores. Flag implausible values (HAZ < -6 or > +6).

indicators.name: Wasting Prevalence (Global Acute Malnutrition)
indicators.definition: Percentage of children 6-59 months with weight-for-height z-score (WHZ) below -2 or MUAC < 125mm or presence of bilateral pitting oedema
indicators.numerator: Number of children with WHZ < -2 or MUAC < 125mm or oedema
indicators.denominator: Total number of children 6-59 months assessed
indicators.dataSource: SMART surveys, nutrition screening, health facility data
indicators.collectionMethod: Anthropometric measurement (weight, height, MUAC tape) and oedema assessment
indicators.frequency: Every 6-12 months in emergency contexts; annually in development contexts

interpretation.critical: ≥ 15% indicates critical situation requiring urgent response

limitations: Point-in-time estimate; can fluctuate seasonally
WHZ and MUAC identify partially different children
Oedema rare in many settings; often missed
indicators.technicalNotes: SMART methodology is standard for surveys. Combined WHZ and MUAC recommended for screening.

indicators.name: Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) Prevalence
indicators.definition: Percentage of children 6-59 months with WHZ < -3 or MUAC < 115mm or bilateral pitting oedema
indicators.numerator: Number of children with WHZ < -3 or MUAC < 115mm or oedema
indicators.denominator: Total number of children 6-59 months assessed
indicators.targetValue: < 2% acceptable; ≥2% indicates need for treatment programming
indicators.dataSource: SMART surveys, nutrition screening, CMAM program data
indicators.frequency: Every 6 months in emergency; annually in development contexts

interpretation.low: < 1% baseline level even in healthy populations

limitations: Relatively rare; requires large samples for precision
Seasonal variation significant
Case-finding methods affect detection
indicators.technicalNotes: SAM subset of GAM. Combined MUAC and WHZ criteria capture most cases.

indicators.name: Exclusive Breastfeeding Rate (0-5 months)
indicators.definition: Percentage of infants 0-5 months who received only breastmilk in previous 24 hours (no other liquids or foods except medicines)
indicators.numerator: Number of infants 0-5 months exclusively breastfed in last 24 hours
indicators.frequency: Annually for monitoring; baseline and endline for programs
limitations: Self-reported; subject to recall and social desirability bias
24-hour recall may not reflect usual practice
Small sample sizes due to narrow age range
indicators.technicalNotes: WHO standard indicator. Water and water-based drinks (teas) break exclusivity.

indicators.name: Minimum Dietary Diversity (6-23 months)
indicators.definition: Percentage of children 6-23 months who consumed foods from ≥5 out of 8 food groups in previous 24 hours
indicators.numerator: Number of children 6-23 months who ate from ≥5 food groups yesterday
indicators.targetValue: ≥70% indicates good dietary diversity at population level
limitations: Measures variety not quantity or frequency
24-hour recall may not represent usual intake
Culturally appropriate food groups needed
indicators.technicalNotes: WHO revised 8-group indicator (2021). Food groups: breastmilk, grains/roots/tubers, legumes/nuts, dairy, flesh foods, eggs, vitamin A-rich fruits/vegetables, other fruits/vegetables.

indicators.name: Minimum Meal Frequency (6-23 months)
indicators.definition: Percentage of children 6-23 months who received minimum number of meals/snacks in previous 24 hours (varies by breastfeeding status and age)
indicators.numerator: Number of children who received minimum meals/snacks

interpretation.concerning: < 50% indicates significant gaps in feeding frequency

limitations: Definitions vary by age and breastfeeding status
Does not capture portion sizes
Cultural definitions of 'meal' vs 'snack' vary
indicators.technicalNotes: Minimum: breastfed 6-8 months = 2 times; 9-23 months = 3 times. Non-breastfed 6-23 months = 4 times including ≥2 milk feeds.

indicators.name: Anemia Prevalence
indicators.definition: Percentage of children 6-59 months with hemoglobin concentration below age-specific threshold
indicators.numerator: Number of children with Hb < 11.0 g/dL (adjusted for altitude)
indicators.targetValue: < 20% is low; 20-39% moderate; ≥40% is severe public health problem (WHO)
indicators.dataSource: Surveys with hemoglobin testing (DHS, MICS, specialized surveys)
indicators.collectionMethod: Capillary blood sample with HemoCue or similar device
indicators.frequency: Every 3-5 years (surveys); not typically program-level monitoring
limitations: Expensive and invasive (blood sample)
Cannot distinguish causes (iron, folate, B12, malaria, infections)
Altitude adjustment needed
Requires trained phlebotomists
indicators.technicalNotes: Threshold: Hb < 11.0 g/dL for children 6-59 months. Adjust for altitude using WHO tables.

indicators.name: Vitamin A Supplementation Coverage
indicators.definition: Percentage of children 6-59 months who received high-dose vitamin A supplement in last 6 months
indicators.numerator: Number of children 6-59 months who received vitamin A in last 6 months
indicators.dataSource: Administrative records, household surveys, coverage surveys
indicators.collectionMethod: Caregiver recall; verification of card/record if available
indicators.frequency: After each campaign (every 6 months); annually in surveys
limitations: Recall bias (caregivers may not remember)
Dose verification difficult without records
Coverage doesn't measure compliance or absorption
indicators.technicalNotes: Standard: 100,000 IU for 6-11 months; 200,000 IU for 12-59 months every 6 months.

indicators.name: Number of Beneficiaries Reached
indicators.definition: Total number of unique beneficiaries (children, pregnant women, etc.) who received program services during reporting period
indicators.numerator: Count of unique beneficiaries receiving services
indicators.targetValue: Program-specific based on coverage goals and target population
indicators.frequency: Monthly, quarterly, or annually depending on program

interpretation.behind: Reaching fewer than planned; investigate barriers

limitations: Number reached ≠ quality of services
Risk of double-counting across sites or time periods
Doesn't capture missed populations
indicators.technicalNotes: Use unique identifiers to avoid double-counting. Report 'individuals' not 'contacts' or 'visits'.

indicators.name: Geographic Coverage
indicators.definition: Percentage of target geographic areas (districts, villages, health facilities) with program services operational
indicators.numerator: Number of target areas with operational services
indicators.targetValue: 100% of planned areas; phased targets if gradual scale-up
indicators.frequency: Quarterly or as sites are added
limitations: Operational ≠ quality or utilization
Doesn't reflect population coverage (people reached)
May mask within-area inequities
indicators.technicalNotes: Define 'operational' clearly (e.g., services available at least 1 day per week with supplies).

indicators.name: SAM Treatment Coverage
indicators.definition: Percentage of children with SAM in target area enrolled in treatment program
indicators.numerator: Number of SAM children enrolled in treatment
indicators.denominator: Estimated SAM caseload in target area
indicators.targetValue: ≥50% is minimum; ≥70% is good; ≥90% is excellent
indicators.dataSource: Program enrollment data and population-based SAM prevalence estimates
indicators.collectionMethod: Service statistics and SLEAC/SQUEAC coverage surveys
indicators.frequency: Quarterly for monitoring; coverage surveys every 6-12 months
disaggregation: Type of SAM (MUAC vs WHZ vs oedema)

interpretation.inadequate: < 50% coverage; most SAM children not reached

limitations: Denominator estimates uncertain
Coverage varies seasonally
Geographic pockets of low coverage may be masked
Methodology (SLEAC vs SQUEAC) affects precision
indicators.technicalNotes: Use SLEAC (small area) or SQUEAC (small area and quality) methods. SPHERE standard ≥50% rural, ≥70% urban.

indicators.name: SAM Treatment Cure Rate
indicators.definition: Percentage of children enrolled in SAM treatment who recover and are discharged as cured
indicators.numerator: Number of SAM admissions discharged as cured
limitations: Default rates affect denominator (if high defaults, cure rate inflated)
Definition of 'cured' must be standardized
Quality of measurement affects reliability
indicators.technicalNotes: Cure = child reaches discharge criteria (MUAC ≥125mm and/or WHZ ≥-2 and no oedema for 2 consecutive weeks).

indicators.name: SAM Treatment Death Rate
indicators.definition: Percentage of children enrolled in SAM treatment who die during treatment
indicators.numerator: Number of SAM admissions who died during treatment
indicators.collectionMethod: Program monitoring with verification where possible
limitations: Deaths after default or discharge not captured
Verification difficult in community settings
May undercount if families don't report deaths
indicators.technicalNotes: Report deaths in treatment separately from deaths post-discharge. Investigate all deaths for quality improvement.

indicators.name: SAM Treatment Default Rate
indicators.definition: Percentage of children enrolled in SAM treatment who are absent for 3+ consecutive visits without formal discharge
indicators.numerator: Number of SAM admissions who defaulted
indicators.collectionMethod: Attendance tracking and defaulter follow-up records
limitations: Some 'defaults' are actually undocumented cures or deaths
Definition of default (3 weeks absent) is arbitrary
Defaulter tracing often incomplete
indicators.technicalNotes: Active defaulter tracing improves data quality. Investigate reasons: access barriers, side effects, family issues.

indicators.name: Average Length of Stay in SAM Treatment
indicators.definition: Average number of weeks children spend in SAM treatment from admission to discharge
indicators.numerator: Sum of weeks in treatment for all discharged children
indicators.targetValue: 6-8 weeks typical; shorter is better if outcomes good
indicators.collectionMethod: Calculate from admission and discharge dates

interpretation.slow: > 10 weeks may indicate quality or supply issues

limitations: Varies by initial severity
Complicated cases skew average
Shorter not always better if quality compromised
indicators.technicalNotes: Track separately for children with vs without medical complications. Monitor alongside cure rate.

indicators.name: Timeliness of Service Delivery
indicators.definition: Percentage of planned service delivery events (distributions, sessions, visits) that occurred on schedule
indicators.numerator: Number of events delivered on time
indicators.dataSource: Program implementation schedules and activity logs
limitations: Doesn't measure quality of services delivered
May penalize programs in insecure or difficult contexts
Definition of 'on time' needs clear thresholds
indicators.technicalNotes: Track reasons for delays (supply, security, weather, staffing) to target improvements.

indicators.name: Stock-Out Rate
indicators.definition: Percentage of program sites that experienced stock-out of essential supplies (RUTF, supplements, etc.) during reporting period
indicators.numerator: Number of sites with stock-out of key supplies
indicators.dataSource: Supply inventory records, site visit reports
indicators.collectionMethod: Stock cards, site monitoring, end-of-month stock reports
limitations: Point-in-time measurement may miss brief stock-outs
Doesn't capture quality of supplies (expired, damaged)
Sites may underreport to avoid blame
indicators.technicalNotes: Track both frequency and duration of stock-outs. Investigate root causes (forecasting, procurement, distribution).

indicators.name: Under-5 Mortality Rate
indicators.definition: Probability of dying between birth and age 5 years, expressed per 1,000 live births
indicators.numerator: Number of deaths of children under 5 years
indicators.denominator: Number of live births (over same time period or cohort)
indicators.calculation: Complex calculation from survey or vital registration data
indicators.collectionMethod: Birth history in household surveys or vital registration
indicators.frequency: Every 3-5 years (surveys); continuous where vital registration exists

interpretation.high: 50-100 per 1,000 indicates major child survival challenges

limitations: Not attributable to specific nutrition programs
Requires large sample sizes and complex methodology
5-year reference period; reflects past not current conditions
Attribution impossible
indicators.technicalNotes: Nutrition programs should NOT claim to measure impact on U5MR. Use population-level data for context only.

principles: Accuracy: Measured correctly with minimal error
Timeliness: Available when needed for decisions
Validity: Measures what it claims to measure

easeLevels.easy: Simple measurement with basic training; low resource requirements
easeLevels.moderate: Requires trained staff and standardized methods; moderate resources
easeLevels.difficult: Requires specialized equipment, extensive training, or invasive procedures; high resources
